doc.after: Terminal 3, which opened on 28 October 2004,[20] replaced Terminal 1 as the main international gateway to and from Israel. The building was designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill (SOM).[21][22] Moshe Safdie & Associates[23] and TRA (now Black and Veatch)[21] designed a linking structure and the airside departure areas and gates. Ram Karmi[21] and other Israeli architects were the local architects of record. The inaugural flight was an El Al flight to John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York City.
